author: m.kalinin
content: I don't think it depends on whether a slot or a block number is used to mark the transition. Entire chain history won't be required by consensus anymore and validators may use this opportunity to prune unnecessary data e.g. after finality. Some of the apps that rely on the history will need to be able to download it from somewhere and one of the questions whether we support it on L1 by retaining a part of ETH63 protocol responsible for chain history or defer it to anything else like services that e.g. shares big chunks of history via bittorrent. My preference would be to retain headers, blocks and receipts downloader until we're convinced that there is a reliable replacement for it. ENR may be used to mark nodes that stores history on discovery layer. Keeping the history downloader would require keeping eth1 block format after the merge.

author: timbeiko
content: <@!425572898787426305> what I was trying to get at is basically how easy/hard do we want to make it for people to fork against PoS? For example, if we try and time it with the difficulty bomb, then the pre-merge chain will need an explicit fork to keep going. If we don't, then maybe it continues and "forks by default" (ex: miners still mine and then the transition to PoS is solely based on running a client that swaps the consensus engine). I think we should be explicit in that design choice, and communicate it early to set expectations for the community (ex: "the eth1 chain _will_ keep going with PoW, but "Ethereum" will move to PoS at X time" vs. "we expect after block Y, no more blocks will be mined on the PoW chain unless someone explicitly creates a fork")

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm a big fan of the former personally, though I wouldn't be opposed if we *happen* to get the ice age timer just right.

author: holgerd77
content:
I think we shouldn't make it too easy for people to just "jump on the bus" and keep the old chain going. This will likely be extremely attractive to short-term squeeze a lot of money out of this and to leverage the situation of people not so deep in the matter  being confused on what the correct Ethereum is. And this will likely be more severe the stronger a potential old chain remains, not much to win of this situation.

A remaining PoW chain also counteracts on the positive environmental impact the switch to PoA will have.
